intro: Alepidea amatymbica var. microbracteata, commonly known as the small-bract alepidea, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family, characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that typically bloom in summer. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of fragrant, white or pale blue flowers. It is often found in rocky outcrops and sandy soils, adapting well to drought conditions. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping in dry climates.
